reviewText: Milestone set out to succeed playstation 2's Tourist Trophy as the modern motorcycle racing simulator. It however falls very short of that goal. Graphics are last generation quality that somehow taxes modern video cards. The only positive things I could say about the game is it's selection of bikes and gear. But it falls short from there. It feels very shallow and geared towards the casual gamer/racing fan.\n\nShort-comings in on track riding is what ruins the game the most. It is the same arcade style simulation (an oxymoron) engine as the previous MotoGP games. Trailbraking deep is ridiculous and offers no feedback when the front wheel is at it's limit. The reactions of the bike to too much throttle is the same for every bike. Turning into the first corner is always the same even if the race just started and the front tire is still cold". Then there are the small missing details. No clutch lever use even on the older bikes. The throttle hand works but the brake lever is never used
date: never mind the rear brake pedal on the right foot. There are ZERO braking markers for non-track circuits. Only occasionally is there a reference point like a tree or a fence

The AI will insist on it's line even if you're in front of it and worst of all will not brake if you plan on braking earlier than it. The AI is also on a very suboptimal line

The set up of the game progression is obviously an afterthought to Milestone as there is NO QUALIFYING SESSION. YOU ARE ALWAYS 8TH. reviewText:
Ride is probably the best motorcycle video game since Tourist Trophy on PS2. There's been many MotoGP and WSBK games, but not many that use real-world motorcycles. I do enjoy riding some of the lesser known, or less racing-orientated bikes, its unusual.

The gameplay is good, not amazing, but good. Sometimes the rider can be a little sluggish, almost like a deliberate input lag of sorts. Its most noticeable when switching directions quickly in a chicane, the rider will be noticeably delayed in swapping his body position on the bike. Sometimes the 'simulation' style of gameplay where excessively hard braking or hard acceleration causes the bike to squirm or slide aren't particularly smooth or realistic. There isn't that many tracks in the game, the selection will get repetitive after a while.

The graphics are ok, the bikes and tracks look fair enough but the riders standing helmetless next to the bikes in the menus look ridiculous. 10years have passed since video game characters looked this simplistic.

The audio, where do I start? Its terrible. Truly aweful. The bikes noises are appalling, I turned them off long ago, like some weird electronically generated whine. The best motorcycle engine noises in a video game ever, are in Burnout Paradise. And bikes are a side show in that game! Come on! Get your act together.

Summary:

Pros:

- Great Selection of bikes, even some older 80's and 90's calssics.
- Fast access to decent bikes, no need to spend hours riding slow bikes (unless you want to).
- Decent on-bike graphics.
- Decent controls.
- Bike customization is limited, but still relatively well implemented. A tuned bike is still noticeably faster than the standard version.

Cons:

- The sound is abysmal. Bikes sound dreadful.
- Some glaring omissions as far as bikes are concerned.
- Helmetless riders look ridiculous, very dated.
- Controls can sometimes feel delayed.
- Some occassional dodgey slides where the physics don't add up.
- Bike customization could have been better. Custom paint jobs, maybe even workshop support for cutom graphics kits etc. Why can I remove all the mirrors and indicators on some, but some leave the indicators when you choose this option? Where are the race fairings with no lights?
- Limited number of tracks.

Ultimately if you like bike racing games, this one is great, I may have been critical, but it can be very fun and its nice racing around on something that isn't necessarily a fully fledged race bike.

reviewText: As far as motorcycle games go, I've played none better.  Well, truth be told, I've played none at all, but as a rather adventurous real-life rider who cut his teeth on the winding roads of Oregon's wine country and coastal mountain range, I can say that the physics and bike handling are spot-on.  Especially when traction control is off, taking a corner too wide and getting off-road while leaned over will often result in a low-side bail, just like real life.  Cornering correctly at the highest speed you can, only to lean in the other direction and take the next, has a lot of weight, as it should; and it's very satisfying to get it right.  This does impart a certain learning curve since, even though bikes can turn on a dime
date:
they can't literally turn on a dime; there are nuances to the timing of brakes, throttle, and cornering that are not the same with cars, and you notice it much more when using a controller.  There's a certain finesse to timing ahead for your corners, but though some may feel that this makes the game unplayable, I find the challenge refreshing, and the difficulty not at all unfair.
The graphics are decent and the framerate stays smooth on my four-year-old computer (three-year-old graphics card) using maximum settings and 1.5GB environment textures.  I'd like to see how this looks on a newer computer, but alas... money.
The sound is where I have to dock some points.  While there's not much you can do to accurately synthesize an engine's sound and make it react to user input without reams of code (that I know of...), the bikes sound good, considering.  It's during momentous occasions such as crashes where the sound design really stinks, because while there might be a clunk or two, there's no horrible crunch, no grinding of metal and fiberglass as your bike flips and slides down the road, no scraping of leather as your character does the same.  It really removes a lot of impact from a corner taken too fast or too late.
Lastly, beware the bugs.  I read that this was originally slated for Stateside release in June, but I have it, and it seems as though it should have been held back until then.  I enjoy it quite a bit, but it's very irritating that my Ducati Diavel's exhaust pipes, turn signals, license plate, intake grills, and mirror stalks are all invisible.  I've heard of other people experiencing similar issues with graphics, and this really shouldn't be in a finished product.
All in all, though, foibles aside, I am having a ton of fun with Ride.  I now live in southern Minnesota, where you can't push your bike's cornering ability without risking a year's income on a potential speeding ticket, so this comes close to taking care of my lean cravings.  Hopefully Milestone will have a patch soon to take care of the bugs, and maybe the sound problems.  In any case, though, buy this game if you want a proper bike simulator.  It rips.

voteText: I want to share my opinion of the game to help you decide. Overall
helpfulPercent: the game is good especially if you're a motorbike lover. However
votesHelpful: it still lacks tracks to race in in my opinion. The game forces you to start with one of 3 naked bikes and I thought it was rather uncool to force you to start with a specific type of bike. That being said
votesTotal:
the progression until you buy a new bike that you like is quick and I now have realized that naked bikes aren't that bad actually.

The game allows you to buy parts for your bikes from aesthetic parts to performance enhancing ones. It also allows you to customize your rider avatar's face and gears (apparel) as well.

The game feels easy to play even with pro physics and no assists especially if you compare it to MotoGP 14. It could be because the bikes are slower than those in MotoGP. But this brought a more arcade feeling to the game than Milestone's MotoGP 14.

Other than the lack of tracks the only other gripe I have is the inability to select the number of laps in any race we participate in (with the exception of online games).

Do note that there's no weather in game neither is day/night setting. I think every track is set to certain pre-programmed time setting. Milestone has a habit of giving you just good enough game without trying to make it really superb.

Online is enjoyable too with stangers or even more with friends.

UPDATE 2 APRIL 2015
Now that I have spent more on the game I have more to share.

The difficulty of the game increases as you upgrade from lower powered bikes to higher ones. Riding a supersport bike may be too easy compared to riding a motoGP bike in Milestone's other game but riding a modern superbike is not so easy. In fact it can feel a bit too difficult. That is until you adapt to the changes.

Wheelie and stoppie happen a lot when you ride a bike with respectable horsepower unless you turn anti wheelie option to full (modern bikes have that tech actually!). Wheelie forces you to go easy on the throttle thus slowing you down despite  the bike's increased power rating. Opening up on the throttle aggresively will slow you down as your bike performs unintended wheelies.

Furthermore
votesFunny:

The game crashes to desktop when you try to  exit and sometimes when loading it just freezes although the likely occurence of the later is not that high.

Perhaps one of the most annoying bug is that rewind doesn't always work and when it doesn't it costs you the race thus in-game money

reviewText:
As someone who rides a motorcycle in reality yet can't ride anything bigger than 125cc due to some stupid British law, I figured buying this game would somewhat alleviate the desire for more speed, and it has. Not entirely but to some degree it has. In terms of gameplay this game is fantastic, going round corners at god knows what speed looks and feels awesome, the physics seem lifelike (from what I can tell), and it is genuinely challenging if you turn up the AI difficulty and turn the assists off. Racing in this game is by far the best fun I've had in a video game this year. The only thing that's bad about the gameplay is the godawful engine sounds. The Aprillia RS250 sounds like the various speeds on a marital aid as you go up through the revs, the Suzuki GSXR1000 K5 sounds muffled, as if you've got your ears plugged and all of the V-Twin Ducati's just sound boring. One of the most significant things about a motorcycle is that they resemble what hell would sound like, not what a hairdryer sounds like. Aside's from the barely viable engine sounds, the gameplay is fantastic.

The menu's however are not. Sure, the backgrounds are pretty, but the text and text boxes are just bland. Navigating the menu's is like trying to force spaghetti up a cat's backside. I have spent a good 3 out of my current 16.7 hours playing this game sidescrolling left and right, be it trying to choose/upgrade a bike, pick an event or simply change my character's helmet. However, ironically, when you're about to purchase yourself a new motorcycle and you go to pick a manufacturer to choose from, all of said manufacturer's are laid out in a nice, easy to navigate grid menu, yet once you pick your desired motorcycle manufacturer you go back to the slow, dimwitted sidescrolling mess that they call a  menu, it's like being stuck in a world of Soup with only a fork. Why is that simple, easy to use grid menu not implemented in ANY OF THE OTHER MENU'S?

So in conclusion, if you manage to make it through the seven levels of menu hell and start a race, you will enjoy yourself. Hopefully they'll improve the engine sounds because right now they barely resemble anything that combusts.

TL:DR
Gameplay is good, apart from the poor engine sounds.
Menus are difficult to navigate and as aesthetically pleasing as a small bowl of vomit balanced on Emma Watson's nose.

reviewText:
Very nice game, Although has a console feel that I really dont like that much (going between menus with bizarre loading times)
The driving feel is very good. I played SBK X for a while and I liked that one as well, IF you've played a milestone bike game you should feel at home.
Still some problems with the not so realistic feel of the bike sometimes, I mean a bike is VERY nimble in real life, you can lean from one side to the other very quickly : in this game you have to change suspension settings to get closer to reality, and you get negative effects from that (less stability).
Still this is acceptable and you can have a lot of fun.

Does not have a lot of tracks at the moment, which is strange because they already had them in earlier games (in SBK X and previous moto GP games you had most popular tracks like brno, mugello, mazda raceway laguna seca etc.
A few open road tracks : need way more real open roads (and i mean not going in circles with laps, i mean a real road like there are sometimes in rally games)

Also city tracks , which I dont like so much (all 90° turn... it gets old)

Lots of bikes ! That's awesome. very well detailed, many categories like historical, naked, sportbikes, of all displacements.
Some groups are unbalanced for racing (you get MT07 or 696 pitted against a 848 , I think they should categorize in relation with horsepower instead of displacement.)
Other example in supersport category: 600cbr, 636 ninja, MV agusta 800 3 cylinder : too much difference in hp

Wasn't very expensive so I got what a paid for but.. I really hope they develop on this base because it could very well be a wonderful title.
I won't hesitate to buy DLC's to expand on it (bikes, tracks)

So.. why do I not recommend it ?
-Milestone is deaf and mute , PR is nowhere to be seen, many users have game breaking bugs and nothing happens
-Loading screens are actually preventing me from launching the game right now, I mean it feels like playing playstation 1 back in the day

reviewText:
bought the game last week on sale, and have to say i'm really enjoying it after putting a few hours in. there are plenty of different bikes to ride from 250 2-strokes up to race prepared machines, all with customisation which is well recieved. customisation doesnt end at the bikes, with the rider, riding style and equipment also interchangeable as you earn cash while racing.

Being a bike rider and occasional trackday goer in real life i'm always going to give this a go, i have played milestone bike games in the past, as well as playing the demo before buying, so knew what to expect and i'm not disappionted. the bikes handle nicely and i think there is a good balance between arcade and 'realistic'. i havent had any bad experiences with bugs and glitches...yet, i'm sure they will show up eventually. sometimes i have found the collisions with either other riders or walls/curbs to be a bit funny at times though, but i think thats more a physics thing than bugs.

I'll just rattle off some pro's and cons to keep it concise. I'm only focusing on singleplayer experiences (havent tried multiplayer or even know if there is any!)

Pros
- Its fun
- customisation is good, but always room for more
- nice range of bikes to try
- mechanics/physics so far seem pretty solid
- runs perfectly and smoothly

Cons
- For me the AI arent aggressive or fast enough, i'm usually multiple seconds per lap faster on the hardest difficulty. They take some odd lines sometimes
- Lacking tracks, would be nice to see some BSB circuits and real road races like NW200, IoMTT, PPIHC and Macau since we have the MotoGP game for the flagship grand prix circuits (although phillip island and mugello wouldnt go amiss)
- Lack of support from the developers is quite alarming, its quite shocking really
- Lack of Mod support
- Sounds are a bit flat and generic, even for road bikes

To be frank, if the developers really cared about what the fans want, most of the issues i've highlighted could probably be resolved with mods, but from what i have read they repeatedly ignore constructive critisism to include things or fix issues and since i havent seen any issues yet all i can really say is theres no smoke without fire, and i hope if they don't fix or add stuff here then they will for RIDE2 if thats going to happen. Try the demo, buy it if you like it, you can always get a refund if you play under 2hours and run into issues.

I'd rate RIDE 6/10 but i would only really reccommend it to bike fans, Its a good game and one of the better bike games going, but it won't stack up in terms of pure racing for people coming from car games if that makes sense. Add some more real decent tracks as outlined above, better audio and mod support and you would have a solid 9/10 bike game here, so its a shame really.

reviewText:
Wow, what a game! -8/10
10 hours played
Motorcycle owner/fan

*MUST BE PLAYED WITH A CONTROLLER*- I can not emphasize this enough
There is no way to get the accuracy and finesse required out of a keyboard(at least using the most realistic physics). With a controller not only can you modulate the gas, brakes, and turning angle in a fluid way (which is extremely important to get a clean line), but you also get force feedback-which adds to the experience immensley. Every shift has a little rumble to it, you can feel when your tires are reaching/passing their grip threshold, and it's much easier to tell when you're close to the wall/another rider. I would not bother playing this game without one.
PROTIP FOR NEXT GAME- VR/steam controller native suppourt would be amazing.

Pros:
-Good graphics, Excellent detail in all of the bike models, all the way down to the proper speedo/tach layout.
-The tracks are fun and challenging, once again a lot of work went into making sure everything felt real, right down to the skidmarks on the road. Additional tracks would be nice, even as dlc(pikes peak pls). The crowds are your standard racing game low detail model but that really isn't why one plays the game.
-A decent amount of character customization and an excellent amount of riding style customization. I was amazed when I figured out how tweakable this was.
-The reverse function is super helpful when having issues with a certain corner. It allows you to reverse approximately the last 15 seconds and even change cameral angles to figure out exactly what the issue is. This feature should be in every racing game
-The first person perspective inside the helmet is very involving. The sensation of speed has been translated very well to a video game, even including accurate sounding wind buffeting, blurring of vision and helmet shaking.
-The mechanics, for the most part, are faithfully accurate to motorcycling. Using the brakes properly has been the hardest thing for me to figure out but I am starting to get it. *Big asterisk* There is no clutch control, which, while really only needed for starting, still removes a major component of a race, especially in drag races. This would be an awesome addition to subsequent games.
-Extensive motorcycle roster--includes basically every major production superbike and naked bike from 2015 - INCLUDING THE MOTHERF***ING LIGHTNING 218 OMGGGGGG. All bikes have all the main customization options that are normally changed. I wish the was a bit more variety of options in a few areas, namely tires and rims but that really isn't an issue.
-A decent amount of bike setup customization including, preload, spring stiffness, and preload with the top tier suspension, and full gearbox ratio customization with the top tier gearbox. *Things to add* Steering angle, more levels of gearbox and suspension customization, rear swingarm length, steering dampener settings, ecu timing and fueling, new throttle profiles, and EXTREMELY IMPORTANTLY, the ability to change settings on the fly to feel the difference and make it easier to experiment with different setups to find what works for you. It's annoying to have to go through three loading screens everytime you want to make an adjustment. A dyno would be nice too.

Cons, and there are a few big ones:
-THE BIGGEST PROBLEM WITH THIS GAME--Bike sound. While the sounds of different bikes vary appropriately according to displacment, engine arrangement, and exhaust, it's very obvious that not much money was put toward making the bikes sound real. When you're making a game with the sole intent of creating the most accurate bike simulator out there, this is hugely important. Does it do the job? Yes, I can shift at the proper time based on the sound. Does it add to the experience? NO. It most definitely removes from it. All the bikes have this wierd low quality synthesizer-esque sound that is just bad. I almost didn't buy the game because of this. The exhaust and intake systems should also have a more realistic effect on the overall sound.
-Controller integration, while superb with actual gameplay, does not properly transfer to the replay and picture taking functions. There is no way for me to save screenshots, which might be an issue with keyboards as well. Many of the main and contextual menus do not properly display controller buttons. Also, RB is reserved for the chat function which I'm sure most people will not be using--especially in the MIDDLE OF A RACE. Complete absurdity.
-No way to practice on a track in career mode-just an extra hassle and a few loading screens to switch to time trial but nevertheless annoying for something that is so essential to the game.
-No real sense of career progression at least in this point in the game. It feels like there's just a bunch of tracks that I will eventually win. The player should start out in low stakes, low displacement, public, ametur races and have to work their way up to the big leagues. The amount of money you get from even the lowest tier career mode races is enough to buy a new bike every 2-3 races. While it's nice to have access to the coolest bikes right from the get go it cheapens their value. All bikes should be available outside of career mode, but you should really have to work to earn them inside it.
-Mirrors do not function

Additional ways for the game to be improved:
-More extensive career mode. Sponsorship, factory and private teams, custom works parts, rivalries, greater acceptance of non-podium spots(to encourage playing on harder modes), qualifying, no restarts on official races(although I feel the rewind function to be neccesary to deal with the random crap that comes with the fact that this is a simulation and not real life), better integration of team members, multiple seasons, and more varied lengths of races are some ways to improve this.
-Tire, brake pad, slider, and chain wear would all be nice to see in addition to the already existing need to replace oil every few races (which is a nice touch)
-More bike customization options. Super/Turbocharging, Fuel injection system hardware, High-compression heads and forged pistons and cranks, different camshaft profiles, frame sliders, and more Colour options. Only being allowed to use the factory available colours is pretty crappy.
-Easier to navigate menus. Mostly evident in the bike customization menu, categories with many colour options are all one massive list. The different styles should be listed independently of colour selection.
-A drafting element
-A NFSU2 style free roam would be neat

TL;DR
A good game provided you can get past the sound. A lot of attention to detail even though this game doesn't seem to have been made on a large budget. Mechanics are good but must be played with a controller. If you like motorcycles and video games, buy it.

reviewText: Before I purchased this on Steam I had hopelessly waited forever for this game to come out. To me it looked almost identical to Forza Motorsports for motorcycles. Kind of a simulator but designed to have arcade abilities to enable less experienced sim folk to enjoy. Well I eventually give up after a year of watching everyone else get it . Time goes on and I build a PC and sure enough here it is. I get excited and make my purchase. I am ready to delve in to deep upgrades and competitive racing enjoying the real sounding and feeling machines so I thought.\nWhat I will complement them on is the 3rd person view and graphics in most cases seem pretty decent but it ends there. Upon starting the game for the first time I realize that the amount of options to enhance graphics or disable depending on your build was absolutely pathetic. The online doesnt work at all despite it telling you you have created a valid account. It just keeps telling me failed to authenticate" which is dismal to say the least. For the sake of a short"ish" review I will move on and not get too hung up.\nNow I am in the game and buy my first bike. The sound is nothing like the real thing and obviously it looks like a stock bike so I head on over to the garage to upgrade and maybe see some info on my bike. By the way the dealership completely sucks. It has no interaction or detail. Its just 5 bar stats going from 0-10 and basic specs. Well inside the parts list I realize there are only oil change
recommended: two brands of exhaust (and obviously Akropovic paid the higher dollar to have their exhaust used here because their exhausts give way more power which is completely wrong in the real world) and wait for it.......... two brands of air filter. The supposive "customize your machine" is a load of crock also. You can change brake lines
voteText:
and pick between usually two to three factory colors for your machine. Not even a paint shop on this game its so plain and empty.
The mechanics of the game seem to be very similar to MotoGP while on the track excluding the tire slippage and spinning are lacking in a realistic way. There is no clutch option at all. The tuning is also a joke. Its pretty much a slider bar for five basic catagories of suspension and a few on and off switches for TCS . I think you are stuck in ABS on . reviewText:
Wow, what a game! -8/10
10 hours played
Motorcycle owner/fan

*MUST BE PLAYED WITH A CONTROLLER*- I can not emphasize this enough
There is no way to get the accuracy and finesse required out of a keyboard(at least using the most realistic physics). With a controller not only can you modulate the gas, brakes, and turning angle in a fluid way (which is extremely important to get a clean line), but you also get force feedback-which adds to the experience immensley. Every shift has a little rumble to it, you can feel when your tires are reaching/passing their grip threshold, and it's much easier to tell when you're close to the wall/another rider. I would not bother playing this game without one.
PROTIP FOR NEXT GAME- VR/steam controller native suppourt would be amazing.

Pros:
-Good graphics, Excellent detail in all of the bike models, all the way down to the proper speedo/tach layout.
-The tracks are fun and challenging, once again a lot of work went into making sure everything felt real, right down to the skidmarks on the road. Additional tracks would be nice, even as dlc(pikes peak pls). The crowds are your standard racing game low detail model but that really isn't why one plays the game.
-A decent amount of character customization and an excellent amount of riding style customization. I was amazed when I figured out how tweakable this was.
-The reverse function is super helpful when having issues with a certain corner. It allows you to reverse approximately the last 15 seconds and even change cameral angles to figure out exactly what the issue is. This feature should be in every racing game
-The first person perspective inside the helmet is very involving. The sensation of speed has been translated very well to a video game, even including accurate sounding wind buffeting, blurring of vision and helmet shaking.
-The mechanics, for the most part, are faithfully accurate to motorcycling. Using the brakes properly has been the hardest thing for me to figure out but I am starting to get it. *Big asterisk* There is no clutch control, which, while really only needed for starting, still removes a major component of a race, especially in drag races. This would be an awesome addition to subsequent games.
-Extensive motorcycle roster--includes basically every major production superbike and naked bike from 2015 - INCLUDING THE MOTHERF***ING LIGHTNING 218 OMGGGGGG. All bikes have all the main customization options that are normally changed. I wish the was a bit more variety of options in a few areas, namely tires and rims but that really isn't an issue.
-A decent amount of bike setup customization including, preload, spring stiffness, and preload with the top tier suspension, and full gearbox ratio customization with the top tier gearbox. *Things to add* Steering angle, more levels of gearbox and suspension customization, rear swingarm length, steering dampener settings, ecu timing and fueling, new throttle profiles, and EXTREMELY IMPORTANTLY, the ability to change settings on the fly to feel the difference and make it easier to experiment with different setups to find what works for you. It's annoying to have to go through three loading screens everytime you want to make an adjustment. A dyno would be nice too.

Cons, and there are a few big ones:
-THE BIGGEST PROBLEM WITH THIS GAME--Bike sound. While the sounds of different bikes vary appropriately according to displacment, engine arrangement, and exhaust, it's very obvious that not much money was put toward making the bikes sound real. When you're making a game with the sole intent of creating the most accurate bike simulator out there, this is hugely important. Does it do the job? Yes, I can shift at the proper time based on the sound. Does it add to the experience? NO. It most definitely removes from it. All the bikes have this wierd low quality synthesizer-esque sound that is just bad. I almost didn't buy the game because of this. The exhaust and intake systems should also have a more realistic effect on the overall sound.
-Controller integration, while superb with actual gameplay, does not properly transfer to the replay and picture taking functions. There is no way for me to save screenshots, which might be an issue with keyboards as well. Many of the main and contextual menus do not properly display controller buttons. Also, RB is reserved for the chat function which I'm sure most people will not be using--especially in the MIDDLE OF A RACE. Complete absurdity.
-No way to practice on a track in career mode-just an extra hassle and a few loading screens to switch to time trial but nevertheless annoying for something that is so essential to the game.
-No real sense of career progression at least in this point in the game. It feels like there's just a bunch of tracks that I will eventually win. The player should start out in low stakes, low displacement, public, ametur races and have to work their way up to the big leagues. The amount of money you get from even the lowest tier career mode races is enough to buy a new bike every 2-3 races. While it's nice to have access to the coolest bikes right from the get go it cheapens their value. All bikes should be available outside of career mode, but you should really have to work to earn them inside it.
-Mirrors do not function

Additional ways for the game to be improved:
-More extensive career mode. Sponsorship, factory and private teams, custom works parts, rivalries, greater acceptance of non-podium spots(to encourage playing on harder modes), qualifying, no restarts on official races(although I feel the rewind function to be neccesary to deal with the random crap that comes with the fact that this is a simulation and not real life), better integration of team members, multiple seasons, and more varied lengths of races are some ways to improve this.
-Tire, brake pad, slider, and chain wear would all be nice to see in addition to the already existing need to replace oil every few races (which is a nice touch)
-More bike customization options. Super/Turbocharging, Fuel injection system hardware, High-compression heads and forged pistons and cranks, different camshaft profiles, frame sliders, and more Colour options. Only being allowed to use the factory available colours is pretty crappy.
-Easier to navigate menus. Mostly evident in the bike customization menu, categories with many colour options are all one massive list. The different styles should be listed independently of colour selection.
-A drafting element
-A NFSU2 style free roam would be neat

TL;DR
A good game provided you can get past the sound. A lot of attention to detail even though this game doesn't seem to have been made on a large budget. Mechanics are good but must be played with a controller. If you like motorcycles and video games, buy it.

tl;dr Game doesn't have any technical issues for me (though I advise doing your own research first), bikes are absolutely beautiful and a joy to ride. Get it if you're a motorcycle fan.

Full review:
Doesn't honestly deserve the flak it gets.

Encountered no save game issues, and the game runs buttery smooth on my rig. The bikes are beautifully modelled and rendered, and the engines sound fantastic on headphones. The tracks pass by fast enough while I'm riding that the supposed lower quality details do not stand out at all.

Riders are believable and very well animated, and the amount of control finesse you can get over the bike is huge, from extremely hand-holdy assistance to letting you have full control over the brakes individually, and shifting gears manually.

The attention to detail is appreciable especially in the first person helmet view available, it even muffles the engine sound, simulating wearing a full-face helmet.

Though no game can really ever come close to capturing the physical aspect of actually riding a motorcycle, RIDE does a respectable job of it. A solid purchase for motorcycle fanatics and riders, in my mind.

Is this game good? Yes... at sale price.
The pros of this game is the basic gameplay, it's a really fun hybrid of arcade and sim that really nails the balance. It reminds me alot of the old MotoGP game from the early 2000s that leaned more towards sim racing. I'm comparing to modern racers where there is more than just racing. Think of that Gride game where there was a progression from season to season. Think of games like NFS shift (that this game borrows from a bit) where you had different categories you raced in. Yes you kind of have it in this where you race in different classes but it's not as well done. Think of how much customisation you get nowadays.
Basically this is a nice game but quite bland. There aare still some bugs and glitches but nothign that broke gameplay or crashed the game for me. It's all just unpolished and could use more game modes and content.
